that said this gave me the feel of some old school games and not sure I can explain why.

Third one is rather different, and the best one of the three. First two are ok, third is great. :)

Third part has a fast travel map! And a choice for Casual or Expert mode! And no annoying misclick penalty on Casual mode! (Don't know about Expert.)

There are tons of fun minigames, and some rather interesting HO scenes where you have to assemble stuff.

It's a very neat setting full of weird stuff. I like weird. And this is fun even without the shiny colours that usually draw me. It's certainly not bleak either!

You can collect candy canes, and while they're not indicated on the map (I really would prefer more games to show where collectibles are still hidden), there's a reason to find them: You can buy cosmetic upgrades for your HUD with them!

[spoiler]I'd felt sorry for the Clown from the start of the first part. Now he got a happy end. :) [/spoiler]

The game crashed twice during a cut scene (different ones), but restarting, I could repeat the last action and watch the cutscene again without trouble both times.

There was one minigame that I skipped, because I couldn't see how it could be solved. (Made two screenshots of it, if anyone's curious.)

22408865.review:
[h1]A Rollercoaster Ride of Storytelling[/h1]

Hidden Object games live from the stories they tell, some of them take a more "adventure" - Light stance in their task to tell a story. Weird Park Triology does a lot right, while only minor problems rise their ugly head during gameplay.

[b]Graphics: +[/b] The three games have good graphics, only the third supports widescreen fully. 

[b]Sound: ++[/b] Original and fitting soundtrack to the game, some of the tunes catch the mixture of mystery, crime and actual horror or circus setting.

[b]Playability: +[/b] Not a lot of surprises here, some of the riddles are challenging enough not to let a gamer run through this game like a madman, and you should take your time to try out the riddles. If one particular riddle is too tough it can be skipped, or you can quit playing and continue later. The graphics of the hidden objects are quite well, especially the third part with the assembly HOS section is a real nice and relaxing part.

Now for the Genre-typical Scores:

[b]Story: ++[/b] I hope you don't suffer coulrophobia, since this story is about... Clowns, one Clown and a mischievously evil little entity that is. The story suffers some insignificant lapses during the three parts, those might be reasoned away with developing the villain and his victims (when you play the last part you'll finally notice why).

[b]Technical Realisation: ++[/b] If all three parts would have had the technical standard of the last part here would be three plusses, my personal max score. Sadly the first two episodes are neither CE's nor are they fully compatible to widescreen (yeah, turning them into WS actually is changing them into uglyness). The game is on par with some of the other good HOG's.

[b]Extras: +[/b] There isn't too much to explain, only the last game has a lot of extras and a bonus chapter, which actually deepens the story behind the Series. Sadly, the first two aren't so well off with extras. Nonetheless, the Extras in the third part do some compensation.

[b][i]Overall Rating: 9 +[/i][/b] Keep in mind, HOG's are casual games, they don't have much of a replayability, aside some sentimental value. But this triology includes three quite nice and well told stories, one which you actually wish to get deeper and deeper into. It has no fear factor - if you don't suffer coulrophobia - and is quite entertaining.

Last but not least: [b]Value for Money: Moderate[/b] 19,90 € doesn't seem much for three games, but they don't have a really long playtime. And replayability tends to zero. Nonetheless, all three games are actually good HOG's with a lot of story to cover. So the price [i]is[/i] acceptable. If you have a chance to buy it on some sale for cheap, do it. You won't rue the purchase.

[h1]Recommended[/h1]

22173204.review:
[h1]Short version: 78%[/h1]
The Weird Park Trilogy is a great pick at a good price for three solid hidden object games that never drop below fairly decent quality. The atmosphere of the first and the game design if the third episode makes it especially noteworthy for any HOG fan.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Alawar made the right choice when they released Weird Park in the package format on Steam. While it certainly lacks extras like trading cards, the quality of the trilogy justifies the price. Let’s see in details:

[b]Weird Park: Broken Tune: 79%[/b]
Broken Tune is tries to sell itself with the visuals and atmosphere, not the story. The derelict amusement park, haunted by the ghost of a clown, works great as a setting, and it can make anyone forget that the game has almost no plot.
The game mechanics are barebones, but refined. There is a fair amount of backtracking and some challenging puzzles, but the main attractions are the hidden object scenes. They are well-constructed and a joy to play, even if some of them are reused several times.

[b]Weird Park: Scary Tales: 71%[/b]
The second part feels less intuitive. The playable area has expanded, but the game has little identity on its own. The number of the hidden object scenes increased, but their quality dropped.
The story brings back the ghost clown, who, along with his puppet, is now kidnapping children in order to place them in known fairy tale settings because… boredom, I guess. While the plot makes its presence known a lot more, it is paper thin and serves only as an excuse to change the scenery frequently.

[b]Weird Park: The Final Show: 83%[/b]
The third part is, finally, plot-driven: a new protagonist ends up in the nightmare world seen in Scary Tales in order to free a kidnapped boy and the soul of the clown (who is suddenly a good guy now). There is even a bonus episode, where we finally learn the truth behind the jester puppet.
Gameplay is strange, as initially it focuses on sequential hidden object and fragmented object scenes before it settles on the traditional HOG mechanics. It also features cross-inventory item manipulation, a rare sight in this genre. This variety, combined with the abundance of story and stages, is the highlight of the trilogy.

19596351.review:
What’s better than one game about creepy clowns? How about THREE games with creepy clowns! The minds behind these games clearly wanted to induce nightmares so play at your own risk!

[b]Weird Park: Broken Tune[/b]
The first game of the Weird Park Trilogy. You play a detective on a mission to uncover the mystery behind disappearances at an old carnival as well as find another detective who went missing there. The park is haunted by a dead clown’s ghost and the trickster Loki and both will eerily appear around the park to spook you, again, evil freaking clown.

The game play is basic hidden item fair. A fair share of hidden item scenes along with mini games and puzzles to solve. Nothing out of the ordinary. It has spooky music and voice acting, though it’s not the best. Everything you could want in a hidden item game is here, despite it being an older and more basic title.

[b]Weird Park: Scary Tales[/b]
The second installment unfortunately has little to do with the first. You play an entirely different character and, despite defeating him in the first game, you’re pitted against the evil clown Louise and Loki once again. The story is off the walls weird. It could be its own separate title and not even be linked to this trilogy and you wouldn’t notice. I found the story to be the weakest, and most annoying, of the three. Your a random guy who went off the road into Spooksville and you have to save kids you don’t even know.

The game play, graphics and music thankful make the game bearable. It’s fun to play and the puzzles are engaging. The voice acting isn’t stellar but it’s appreciated. Even if you feel the same way as I about the story you’ll be too busy finding hidden objects to really notice, too much anyway.

[b]Weird Park: The Final Show Collector's Edition[/b]
The final act in the war against Loki and Louise, you once again play someone different but you’re brought back to Fairy Gate Park as a journalist. Everything about this game is an improvement from the other two except, in my opinion, the story. The first game was incredibly spooky and unnerving, even causing me to be mad at it for the clowns in it. As the series progresses it becomes less and less scary and more mundane. 18111141.review:
The Weird Park games tell the story of a spoopy ghost clown and his sinister little jester buddy, operating out of an abandoned amusement park. Each installment casts you as some kind of investigator looking into a part of the park's past, and having to assemble crests, collect socks, and shoot crossbows to solve the mystery. They're all hidden object games in that grand European style where the English and the logic are just a little bit off, but you can see the polish get layered thicker and thicker as the series progresses. Honestly, there's a lot of difference between the three games, so I'll talk a little about each one.

Broken Tune is the first in the series, and is about as straight-forward a hidden object game as you can get. You pick up inventory items, you use them on things, you find 12 doodads in hidden object scenes to get another inventory item. There are a few puzzles, but no gimmicks, no item combinations, and no map. However, the game itself is very well laid-out, with items arranged so that they will send you back to areas that have new points of interest. The uses of items are crystal clear, and the hidden object scenes are clean and detailed. One interesting feature of the game is that it is split evenly into two acts, with no backtracking or items shared between halves. The graphics are good, the voice acting is goofy, and it'll last you a good two hours.

Scary Tales is the middle installment and a huge step up from Broken Tune. This one adds more puzzles, cutscenes, and areas to explore. The game is also WAY longer, clocking in at nearly 4 hours. In terms of design, there's more variety to the different areas. The first third of the game is extremely open, allowing you to travel to many different rooms right from the start. This does make the opening act a bit harder, however, because you get a crapload of items at once and no real clear direction for using some of them. After that the game goes into some really creative places and plays with fairy tale concepts. It's a great game to follow the first with, especially since it's more difficult overall.

The Final Show is, unsurprisingly, the last in the series. Again it improves over the previous game, this time adding new variations of hidden object scenes, interactive items you can manipulate, an upgrade system (!), achievements (in-game, not Steam), and a map for ease of travel. Final Show is just as long as Scary Tales if not longer, and is split into convenient chapters with no backtracking between. It also goes full-on crazy with the setting, having only the tutorial set in the real world. Oh yeah, it has a tutorial, too, for some reason. The graphics are fantasic, and there are quite a few voiced NPCs in this one as well, as opposed to the mostly barren games before it. The upgrade system might just be cosmetic, but having something else to find in addition to the necessary items was a treat. There's even a bonus chapter you unlock after beating it that fills in some of the backstory, and is honestly one of the best-designed chapters in the series. My only gripe is that Final Show is harder still than Scary Tales, which pushes it into slightly unfun territory sometimes. In particular, some of the item logic is really questionable. Beyond that, though, it's easily the most polished and deep game of the three.

Taken as a whole, Weird Park Trilogy feels like a great way to get into hidden object games because each part of the series is so different. They form a spectrum from bare-bones to feature-rich, which lets you discover precisely what your taste is. There's even a complete story told across them, though it's perfectly goofy and predictable. It's also hard to beat the value, since you're getting 10+ hours of game in a genre where most will only get you 2. My one piece of advice if you do get into it, though, is to play on the lower difficulties. Whereas the "Expert Modes" in other hidden object games make the puzzles and searches more challenging, all it does in the Weird Park games is eliminate the highlights around hidden object scenes. It's an annoyance made worse by the amount of backtracking you have to do sometimes, because each scene has to be done multiple times at different points in the game. Remember that if you ever get stuck, too... go back and look for a scene that's reactivated. With the hints and the improvements of the later games, though, it shouldn't distract too much from the overall experience. No matter if you're new to hidden object games or an old hand at them, you won't be disappointed.
